articles.title: Momentum Grows for New Treaty on Right to Education
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Students in a pre-primary school classroom in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, 2021.
                    © 2021 Bede Sheppard/Human Rights Watch
          
    


  
Momentum is mounting for a new global treaty to secure every child’s right to free education. This week, countries gathered at the United Nations in Geneva to advance negotiations on an optional protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child.The proposed treaty would close a gap in international law. The convention guarantees free primary education but stops short of requiring governments to deliver free secondary education to all. It is completely silent on the right to early childhood education. The protocol would recognize every child’s right to early childhood education and ensure free public education from pre-primary through the end of secondary.The turnout was striking: 92 countries participated. The initiative is led by Sierra Leone, Luxembourg, and the Dominican Republic, backed by a cross-regional coalition. Five new countries announced support, bringing to 58 the number publicly supportive of advancing the initiative. Closing the meeting, the chair from Sierra Leone – a low-income country that already guarantees 13 years of free education – launched an intensive round of consultations to discuss key principles and develop the foundations of the new treaty. They plan to reconvene in 2026.Several countries showcased reforms they had introduced that are reshaping children’s lives. Spain and France highlighted the transformative power of early childhood education; both introduced three years of free preschool education. Ghana reported soaring enrollment after expanding free secondary education years in 2017, particularly among low-income students. Zambia shared its adoption of free secondary education in 2022, while Ecuador highlighted its constitutional guarantee to free public education, including university. What would make this treaty unique is the central role children have played in its development. Child delegates from Croatia, Indonesia, Liberia, Mexico, and the United Kingdom spoke with urgency about the burden tuition and school fees have on families and what might be achieved in a world where pre-primary and secondary education are truly free. As Karen, 16, from Mexico put it: “This protocol would help millions of children stay in school and would be key to reducing inequalities.”The right to free education is within reach, and countries need to make building the foundations of this treaty a priority. As Roberto, 17, from Liberia, said: “What makes it truly powerful is that we, as children, were part of the process—our voices should shape the outcome.”
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Students in a pre-primary school classroom in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, 2021. © 2021 Bede Sheppard/Human Rights Watch

Momentum is mounting for a new global treaty to secure every child’s right to free education. This week, countries gathered at the United Nations in Geneva to advance negotiations on an optional protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

The proposed treaty would close a gap in international law. The convention guarantees free primary education but stops short of requiring governments to deliver free secondary education to all. It is completely silent on the right to early childhood education. The protocol would recognize every child’s right to early childhood education and ensure free public education from pre-primary through the end of secondary.

The turnout was striking: 92 countries participated. The initiative is led by Sierra Leone, Luxembourg, and the Dominican Republic, backed by a cross-regional coalition. Five new countries announced support, bringing to 58 the number publicly supportive of advancing the initiative. Closing the meeting, the chair from Sierra Leone – a low-income country that already guarantees 13 years of free education – launched an intensive round of consultations to discuss key principles and develop the foundations of the new treaty. They plan to reconvene in 2026.

Several countries showcased reforms they had introduced that are reshaping children’s lives. Spain and France highlighted the transformative power of early childhood education; both introduced three years of free preschool education. Ghana reported soaring enrollment after expanding free secondary education years in 2017, particularly among low-income students. Zambia shared its adoption of free secondary education in 2022, while Ecuador highlighted its constitutional guarantee to free public education, including university.

What would make this treaty unique is the central role children have played in its development. Child delegates from Croatia, Indonesia, Liberia, Mexico, and the United Kingdom spoke with urgency about the burden tuition and school fees have on families and what might be achieved in a world where pre-primary and secondary education are truly free. As Karen, 16, from Mexico put it: “This protocol would help millions of children stay in school and would be key to reducing inequalities.”

The right to free education is within reach, and countries need to make building the foundations of this treaty a priority. As Roberto, 17, from Liberia, said: “What makes it truly powerful is that we, as children, were part of the process—our voices should shape the outcome.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant global initiative to establish a new treaty ensuring free education from early childhood through secondary school, which would close existing legal gaps and benefit millions of children worldwide. The broad international participation and the inclusion of children's voices highlight the meaningful and inclusive nature of this effort, promising substantial positive impact on education access and equality globally.
articles.personality_title: Countries push for new treaty guaranteeing free education from early childhood to secondary school
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Currently, international law guarantees free primary education for children but does not require governments to provide free secondary education or early childhood education. This leaves gaps that many children around the world still face when trying to go to school.

**What happened** – This week, 92 countries met at the United Nations in Geneva to discuss a new treaty called an optional protocol to the Convention on the Rights of the Child. This treaty would ensure every child has the right to free education starting from pre-primary (early childhood) through the end of secondary school. The effort is led by Sierra Leone, Luxembourg, and the Dominican Republic, and 58 countries now openly support it. The group plans to continue working on the treaty and meet again in 2026.

**Impact** – The treaty would fill a major gap by making free education more complete worldwide. Some countries like Spain, France, Ghana, Zambia, and Ecuador have already made changes that show how free early education and secondary school can improve children’s lives. What makes this effort special is that children themselves have helped shape the treaty by sharing how school fees affect their families. For example, Karen, a 16-year-old from Mexico, said the treaty could help millions stay in school and reduce inequality.

**What's next step** – The countries involved will continue talks and consultations to finalize the treaty’s key ideas. They aim to create a strong legal foundation that governments around the world can agree on. When finished, this treaty could encourage many more countries to offer free education from early childhood through secondary school.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A growing global effort is working to create a new treaty that guarantees free education for all children from early years through high school, closing legal gaps and involving children’s voices in the process.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les pays avancent vers un nouveau traité garantissant l'éducation gratuite de la petite enfance au secondaire
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Actuellement, la loi internationale garantit l'éducation primaire gratuite pour les enfants, mais ne contraint pas les gouvernements à fournir une éducation secondaire ou préscolaire gratuite. Cela crée des lacunes auxquelles de nombreux enfants sont confrontés dans le monde.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Cette semaine, 92 pays se sont réunis aux Nations Unies à Genève pour discuter d'un nouveau traité appelé protocole optionnel à la Convention relative aux droits de l'enfant. Ce traité garantirait à chaque enfant le droit à une éducation gratuite dès la petite enfance jusqu'à la fin du secondaire. L'initiative est menée par la Sierra Leone, le Luxembourg et la République dominicaine, et 58 pays soutiennent publiquement ce projet. Le groupe prévoit de poursuivre ses travaux et de se réunir à nouveau en 2026.

**Impact** – Ce traité comblerait un vide important en rendant l'éducation gratuite plus complète dans le monde. Certains pays, comme l'Espagne, la France, le Ghana, la Zambie et l'Équateur, ont déjà montré que l'éducation préscolaire et secondaire gratuite peut améliorer la vie des enfants. Ce qui rend cet effort unique, c’est la participation directe des enfants qui ont partagé l’impact des frais scolaires sur leurs familles. Par exemple, Karen, 16 ans, du Mexique, a déclaré que ce traité pourrait aider des millions d’enfants à rester à l’école et réduire les inégalités.

**Prochaine étape** – Les pays continueront les discussions pour finaliser les principes clés du traité. Ils souhaitent créer une base juridique solide que les gouvernements du monde entier pourront adopter. Une fois terminé, ce traité pourrait encourager beaucoup plus de pays à offrir l’éducation gratuite de la petite enfance au secondaire.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Un effort mondial croissant vise à créer un nouveau traité garantissant l’éducation gratuite pour tous les enfants, de la petite enfance au lycée, en comblant les lacunes juridiques et en incluant la voix des enfants.
articles.personality_title_es: Los países avanzan hacia un nuevo tratado que garantiza educación gratuita desde la primera infancia hasta la secundaria
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Actualmente, la ley internacional garantiza educación primaria gratuita para los niños, pero no obliga a los gobiernos a ofrecer educación secundaria o preescolar gratuita. Esto deja vacíos que muchos niños en el mundo aún enfrentan para ir a la escuela.

**Qué pasó** – Esta semana, 92 países se reunieron en las Naciones Unidas en Ginebra para discutir un nuevo tratado llamado protocolo opcional a la Convención sobre los Derechos del Niño. Este tratado garantizaría el derecho de todos los niños a educación gratuita desde la preprimaria (educación temprana) hasta el final de la secundaria. La iniciativa está liderada por Sierra Leona, Luxemburgo y la República Dominicana, y 58 países ya la apoyan públicamente. El grupo planea continuar trabajando en el tratado y reunirse nuevamente en 2026.

**Impacto** – El tratado llenaría un vacío importante al hacer que la educación gratuita sea más completa en todo el mundo. Algunos países como España, Francia, Ghana, Zambia y Ecuador ya han hecho cambios que muestran cómo la educación gratuita desde la primera infancia y la secundaria puede mejorar la vida de los niños. Lo que hace especial este esfuerzo es que los propios niños han ayudado a dar forma al tratado compartiendo cómo las cuotas escolares afectan a sus familias. Por ejemplo, Karen, una niña de 16 años de México, dijo que el tratado podría ayudar a millones a seguir en la escuela y reducir la desigualdad.

**Próximo paso** – Los países continuarán las conversaciones y consultas para finalizar las ideas clave del tratado. Buscan crear una base legal fuerte que los gobiernos de todo el mundo puedan aceptar. Cuando termine, este tratado podría motivar a muchos más países a ofrecer educación gratuita desde la primera infancia hasta la secundaria.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Un esfuerzo global creciente trabaja para crear un nuevo tratado que garantice educación gratuita para todos los niños desde la primera infancia hasta la escuela secundaria, cerrando vacíos legales e incluyendo la voz de los niños.

articles.title: ‘The Other Sahel’ shows another side to the region often labelled a ‘conflict zone’
articles.summary: “Resilience and creativity are deeply rooted in Sahelian societies. Today, every artistic project, every cultural initiative, is a direct response to the daily challenges and an act of social transformation.”
articles.content:
The Sahel, an African region stretching from the Atlantic Ocean on the West Coast to the Red Sea on the East Coast, is often reduced to an area of armed conflicts and security crises by the international media.

However, the region also has a vast and varied culture that remains largely unknown outside its borders. Through the documentary “The Other Sahel — The Resilience of Artists in Mali, Niger, and Burkina Faso” by Joël Hevi, a Togolese journalist and cultural entrepreneur active in the creative industry, a community of artists, creators, and cultural entrepreneurs aims to provide a more diverse and nuanced picture of this region.

In this documentary, as part of the African Union Media Fellowship, Joël Hevi tells the story of various artists who rely on resilience and creativity to face the challenges in three Sahelian countries: Mali, Niger, and Burkina Faso. He explained the reasons behind his project in a face-to-face interview with Global Voices.

Jean Sovon (JS): How did you come up with the idea of promoting culture in the Sahel?



Joël Hevi (JH): Le Sahel est trop souvent réduit à une carte de crises, de conflits et de catastrophes dans les récits dominants. Cette représentation simpliste occulte la richesse des histoires humaines qui s’y déroulent chaque jour. Les artistes et créateurs que j’ai rencontrés sont des bâtisseurs, des visionnaires qui transforment la contrainte en opportunité. Pour moi, raconter leurs parcours, c’est montrer une autre facette de la région, où résilience, créativité et sens de la communauté sont les moteurs d’un changement durable. Mon objectif avec The Other Sahel était de donner la voix à ces acteurs trop souvent marginalisés, de montrer que derrière les défis, il y a des initiatives qui réinventent la culture et la société. En donnant de l’espace à ces histoires, le documentaire invite le spectateur à déconstruire les clichés et à percevoir le Sahel comme une région dynamique et créative, où les habitants sont eux-mêmes les auteurs de leur récit.

Joël Hevi (JH): In mainstream narratives, the Sahel is all too often labelled a region of crises, conflicts, and tragedies. This unnuanced portrayal obscures the wealth of human stories that unfold there every day. The artists and creators I interviewed are master builders and visionaries who turn limitations into opportunities. Telling their stories shows the other side to this region, where resilience, creativity, and a sense of community drive sustainable change. My objective for “The Other Sahel” was to make these actors, who are too often marginalized, heard and show that behind the challenges lie initiatives reimagining culture and society. By sharing these stories, the documentary invites viewers to break down stereotypes and see the Sahel as a dynamic and creative region, where citizens are the authors of their own stories.

JS: How does art become a means of communication for Sahelian artists?

JH: Ces créateurs du Mali, Burkina et du Niger utilisent l’art comme un langage universel capable de transcender les frontières, de fédérer les communautés et de créer des espaces d’expression et de dialogue. Au-delà, l’art est aussi un outil concret de transformation sociale. Les initiatives culturelles stimulent l’économie locale, renforcent la solidarité communautaire et permettent aux jeunes et aux femmes de trouver un espace pour leur voix et leur créativité. À travers les initiatives que j'ai vues par exemple à l’espace Boul Yam à Ouagadougou, capitale politique du Burkina Faso, l’art devient un levier puissant pour faire entendre les aspirations et les réalités des plus jeunes et des populations locales. C'est l'exemple du festival Les Récréâtrales, tenu du 24 octobre au 2 novembre à Ouagadougou.

JH: These creators from Mali, Burkina Faso, and Niger use art as a universal language that transcends borders, unites communities, and creates spaces of expression and dialogue. Moreover, art is also a practical tool for social transformation. Cultural initiatives stimulate local economies, strengthen community solidarity, and enable young people and women to find spaces to share their opinions and creativity. For example, through the initiatives I saw in Espace Boul Yam (Knowledge Development Space), a cultural center in Ouagadougou, the political capital of Burkina Faso, art has become a powerful tool for sharing the aspirations and realities of young people and local populations alike. An example is the Récréâtrales festival, a pan-African space for theatrical writing, creation, research, and distribution, held in Ouagadougou from October 24 to November 2.

This festival allowed these artists to assert their resilience against crises.

JS: How does this documentary transcend stereotypes found in international media?

JH: Les récits dominants ont souvent tendance à représenter le Sahel uniquement à travers le prisme de la violence et de l’instabilité. The Other Sahel propose un regard inverse, qui met en lumière la vitalité culturelle et la créativité des habitants. On y voit des artistes et entrepreneurs culturels qui innovent, organisent des projets collectifs et préservent leur patrimoine malgré les crises. Cette représentation démontre que le Sahel est un espace de vie, d’ingéniosité et d’opportunités, loin de l’image unique de fragilité. Le documentaire casse également l’idée selon laquelle la culture ne peut pas coexister avec les difficultés économiques et sécuritaires. Il montre que l’art et l’entrepreneuriat culturel sont des outils de résistance, de réappropriation et de transformation sociale. En donnant une voix aux acteurs locaux, le film rééquilibre le récit international et invite le spectateur à voir le Sahel comme une région riche de talents, d’initiatives et de récits humains inspirants.

JH: Mainstream narratives often only show the Sahel through the prism of violence and instability. “The Other Sahel” offers an opposite viewpoint, showcasing its cultural vitality and citizen creativity. We see innovative artists and cultural entrepreneurs planning collective projects and preserving their heritage despite the crises. Rather than the typical image of fragility, this portrayal shows that the Sahel is a space for living, ingenuity, and opportunity. The documentary also challenges the notion that culture cannot exist amid economic and security crises. It shows that art and cultural entrepreneurship are tools of resilience, reappropriation, and social transformation. By making local actors heard, the documentary balances the international narrative and invites the audience to see the Sahel as a region rich in talent, initiatives, and inspiring human stories.

In this documentary (3:56), Zabda, a Burkinabé artist and President of Espace Boul Yam in Ouagadougou, discusses two of this space’s initiatives: “artistic practices” and “cultural discoveries.”

Another initiative is that of photographer Zerbo Siaka, known as Fasky. This initiative showcases his photo exhibition project in which he draws attention to social and human rights issues, especially those affecting women.

JS: What obstacles did you have to overcome in making this documentary?

JH: Je voulais raconter un autre Sahel, celui des créateurs, mais la réalité du terrain a rapidement rattrapé mon intention. J'ai compris que documenter la résilience exigeait d'abord de naviguer à travers l'insécurité, car des voyages par la route entre villes, autrefois possibles, étaient devenus trop risqués. Le niveau de vigilance des autorités a aussi créé une forme de censure subtile. J'ai essuyé des refus et des hésitations de la part de deux artistes au parcours aussi atypique. Chaque interview a nécessité de gagner la confiance des gens, pour qu'ils s'ouvrent sans crainte. Dans certains cas, il a fallu s'appuyer sur des amis journalistes pour atteindre ces voix authentiques.

Ces difficultés ont paradoxalement renforcé le message du film. Elles prouvent que la créativité et la résilience sont des forces qui persistent même dans les conditions les plus difficiles.

JH: I wanted to tell the story of another Sahel, one of its creators. However, the on-the-ground reality soon held up my plans. I realized that documenting their resilience primarily entailed navigating insecurity. The once possible road trips between towns had become too dangerous. The authorities’ level of vigilance also created subtle censorship. I came up against refusals and unwillingness from two artists with atypical backgrounds. Earning people’s trust was essential in each interview so that they would open up without fear. In some cases, we had to rely on journalist colleagues to reach these authentic voices. These challenges have paradoxically strengthened the documentary’s message. They prove that creativity and resilience remain even in the most challenging conditions.

JS: What is the main message that your audience should take away?

JH: Le message central est que la résilience et la créativité sont profondément ancrées dans les sociétés sahéliennes. Chaque projet artistique, chaque initiative culturelle aujourd'hui est une réponse directe aux défis quotidiens et un acte de transformation sociale. Les spectateurs devraient comprendre que le Sahel au-delà des crises qu'il traverse, c'est ce que ses habitants en font avec courage, imagination et solidarité. Je souhaite que le public retienne aussi l’importance de donner une voix aux acteurs locaux et de valoriser leurs initiatives. Derrière les difficultés, il existe des histoires d’espoir et de créativité qui méritent d’être racontées. Le documentaire incite à regarder le Sahel autrement, à célébrer ses voix et à comprendre que la culture est un véritable levier de changement, capable de transformer des vies et des communautés.

JH: The core message is that resilience and creativity are deeply rooted in Sahelian societies. Today, every artistic project, every cultural initiative, is a direct response to the daily challenges and an act of social transformation. The audience should understand that the Sahel, aside from its crises, is what its citizens make of it with their courage, imagination, and solidarity. I also want the public to understand the importance of promoting local actors’ initiatives and making them heard. Behind these challenges lie stories of hope and creativity worth telling. The documentary encourages us to look at the Sahel from a different angle, celebrate its voices, and understand that culture is a driving force for change, capable of transforming lives and communities.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a documentary that challenges negative stereotypes about the Sahel by showcasing the resilience, creativity, and cultural initiatives of local artists in Mali, Niger, and Burkina Faso. It emphasizes the positive social transformation driven by art and cultural entrepreneurship, which fosters community solidarity, economic stimulation, and empowerment of marginalized groups such as youth and women. This story has broad significance as it reshapes international narratives, promotes social inclusion, and uplifts a region often portrayed negatively, providing a hopeful and inspiring perspective with substantial context and detail.

articles.title: Pacific Leaders Should Act Collectively on Climate Relocation
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Leaders assemble at the 2024 Pacific Islands Forum in Nuku'alofa, Tonga, August 26, 2024.
                    © 2024 AP Photo/Charlotte Graham-McLay
          
    


  
Pacific leaders preparing to gather for the Pacific Islands Forum in Solomon Islands this month have accepted a collective responsibility: to act decisively for the many Indigenous communities already living the sobering realities of climate displacement.Over the last decades, abnormally high “king tides” and storms forced one such community, the Solomon Islander people of Walande, to abandon their tiny island home, now submerged by the sea. Families collectively planned to relocate to mainland Malaita but continue to face challenges at their new site as seawater breaches protective seawalls and inundates the community’s traditional food sources. Their experience, documented in a 2025 Human Rights Watch report, is a powerful reminder that relocation, if inadequately supported, risks compounding harm instead of reducing it.No single community or country can address planned relocation, or any other form of climate mobility, alone. That is why leaders at this year’s Pacific Islands Forum should prioritize regional cooperation to tackle these challenges. The Pacific Regional Framework on Climate Mobility (endorsed by leaders at the Forum in 2023) was an important first step. Government leaders should now adopt the Pacific Guidance on Internal Planned Relocation, which offers a blueprint for Pacific governments to center the right to self-determination and other human rights when supporting communities making adaptation decisions.Seventeen member states are expected to attend this year’s forum. articles.content:
Click to expand Image Leaders assemble at the 2024 Pacific Islands Forum in Nuku'alofa, Tonga, August 26, 2024. © 2024 AP Photo/Charlotte Graham-McLay

Pacific leaders preparing to gather for the Pacific Islands Forum in Solomon Islands this month have accepted a collective responsibility: to act decisively for the many Indigenous communities already living the sobering realities of climate displacement.

Over the last decades, abnormally high “king tides” and storms forced one such community, the Solomon Islander people of Walande, to abandon their tiny island home, now submerged by the sea. Families collectively planned to relocate to mainland Malaita but continue to face challenges at their new site as seawater breaches protective seawalls and inundates the community’s traditional food sources. Their experience, documented in a 2025 Human Rights Watch report, is a powerful reminder that relocation, if inadequately supported, risks compounding harm instead of reducing it.

No single community or country can address planned relocation, or any other form of climate mobility, alone. That is why leaders at this year’s Pacific Islands Forum should prioritize regional cooperation to tackle these challenges. The Pacific Regional Framework on Climate Mobility (endorsed by leaders at the Forum in 2023) was an important first step. Government leaders should now adopt the Pacific Guidance on Internal Planned Relocation, which offers a blueprint for Pacific governments to center the right to self-determination and other human rights when supporting communities making adaptation decisions.

Seventeen member states are expected to attend this year’s forum. As the host, Solomon Islands has an opportunity to lead by example. Its forthcoming Standard Operating Procedures on planned relocation should be finalized and adopted swiftly, integrating lessons from communities like Walande and human rights principles from the regional guidance.

Moreover, leaders should commit to operationalizing funds, such as the new Pacific Resilience Facility, in ways that are accessible to communities most at risk. Without adequate funding and national governance frameworks to ensure community-led approaches, regional commitments will remain words on paper.

The theme of this year’s forum, “Iumi Tugeda: Act Now for an Integrated Blue Pacific Continent,” reflects a call to collective action, according to Solomon Islands Prime Minister Jeremiah Manele. To truly act now, Pacific leaders should commit to a regional approach to planned relocation governance that places communities’ voices and rights at its core.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant and meaningful collective effort by Pacific Island leaders to address the urgent and large-scale issue of climate displacement affecting Indigenous communities. It focuses on regional cooperation, human rights-centered relocation policies, and funding mechanisms to support vulnerable populations, demonstrating a positive real-world impact with broad significance and detailed context.
articles.personality_title: Pacific leaders unite to support climate relocation for island communities
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Pacific Island communities face growing threats from climate change, including rising sea levels and stronger storms. Some Indigenous groups have already had to leave their homes because of flooding and damage.

**What happened** – Leaders from 17 Pacific Island countries are meeting at the 2024 Pacific Islands Forum in the Solomon Islands to work together on climate relocation. They are discussing plans to help communities like the Walande people, who had to move after their island was flooded. The forum aims to adopt new regional guidelines that focus on protecting human rights and allowing communities to decide their futures.

**Impact** – This is important because relocating communities without enough support can cause more harm, such as losing traditional food sources or facing unsafe living conditions. The leaders’ plan to cooperate means they can share knowledge, create better policies, and provide funds to help people move safely and keep their culture.

**What's next step** – The Solomon Islands will lead by finalizing new rules for relocation based on lessons from communities like Walande. Leaders will also work to make sure funds, like the Pacific Resilience Facility, reach the people who need them most. This cooperation could serve as a model for how countries handle climate relocation worldwide.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Pacific Island leaders are joining forces to create fair, community-focused plans for climate relocation that respect human rights and provide real support to those affected.

articles.title: European Parliament Representation Office for the Western Balkans, in Tirana
articles.summary: The PE office in Tirana is a strong impetus for the integration and cooperation of the countries of the Western Balkans.
articles.content:
The PE office in Tirana is a strong impetus for the integration and cooperation of the countries of the Western Balkans.

In Tirana, the Albanian capital, the opening of the European Parliament office for the Western Balkans is expected soon.

The Speaker of the Assembly of Albania, Elisa Spiropali, welcomed the EU ambassador, Silvio Gonzato, and the head of the European Parliament’s Office for the Western Balkans in Tirana, Tatiana Mrazikova, at the Assembly’s Presidency.

Spiropali described the office as “the antenna of the European Parliament for the Western Balkans” and stated that it is “a strong impetus for the integration and cooperation of the countries in the region, as well as for Albania’s leadership in these processes.”

The Representation Office will accelerate and support integration processes, as well as promote and strengthen the interaction and support of the European Parliament with the Assembly of Albania and the parliaments of the Western Balkan countries.

In April of this year, the Fourth Intergovernmental Conference was held in Luxembourg, EU-Albania, where another negotiation chapter for the Internal Market was opened.

Albania expects to open the last negotiation chapters within this year, aiming to be ready for membership by 2030.

The Albanian government, the Assembly, the justice system, and all Albanian institutions have reaffirmed their commitment to continue with European reforms to meet all membership criteria.

Support for the country’s integration into the EU has also been provided by the opposition in Albania, while according to the latest Eurobarometer, support for EU membership is high in Albania (91%). (September 4)
articles.reasoning: The opening of the European Parliament Representation Office for the Western Balkans in Tirana represents a significant and tangible step toward regional integration and cooperation, supporting Albania's EU membership aspirations. This development promotes democratic reforms, political cooperation, and stability in a region with broad public support for EU integration, thus having meaningful positive impact on society and governance.
articles.personality_title: European Parliament opens new office in Tirana to boost Western Balkans cooperation
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Western Balkans is a group of countries in Southeast Europe working toward joining the European Union (EU). Albania, one of these countries, is actively preparing to become an EU member by 2030.

**What happened** – A new European Parliament (PE) office for the Western Balkans is opening soon in Tirana, the capital of Albania. The office was welcomed by Elisa Spiropali, Speaker of the Albanian Assembly, the EU ambassador Silvio Gonzato, and Tatiana Mrazikova, head of the new office. This office will serve as a connection point between the European Parliament and the countries of the Western Balkans.

**Impact** – This office will speed up cooperation and support among the Western Balkan countries and the European Parliament. It will help Albania and its neighbors work together on important reforms and political projects. The office strengthens Albania’s role in leading these efforts. Public support for EU membership is very high in Albania, with 91% of people in favor, showing strong local commitment.

**What’s next step** – Albania aims to open its last EU negotiation chapters this year, moving closer to full membership by 2030. The new office will help coordinate these efforts and assist the parliaments in the region to work more closely with the EU. Continued reforms and cooperation are expected to follow.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The opening of the European Parliament’s Western Balkans office in Tirana marks an important step in supporting Albania and its neighbors on their path to EU membership and stronger regional cooperation.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Parlement européen ouvre un nouveau bureau à Tirana pour renforcer la coopération dans les Balkans occidentaux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les Balkans occidentaux sont un groupe de pays en Europe du Sud-Est qui travaillent à rejoindre l’Union européenne (UE). L’Albanie, l’un de ces pays, se prépare activement à devenir membre de l’UE d’ici 2030.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Un nouveau bureau du Parlement européen (PE) pour les Balkans occidentaux va bientôt ouvrir à Tirana, la capitale de l’Albanie. Ce bureau a été accueilli par Elisa Spiropali, présidente de l’Assemblée albanaise, l’ambassadeur de l’UE Silvio Gonzato et Tatiana Mrazikova, responsable du nouveau bureau. Ce bureau servira de lien entre le Parlement européen et les pays des Balkans occidentaux.

**Impact** – Ce bureau accélérera la coopération et le soutien entre les pays des Balkans occidentaux et le Parlement européen. Il aidera l’Albanie et ses voisins à travailler ensemble sur des réformes importantes et des projets politiques. Le bureau renforce le rôle de l’Albanie dans la direction de ces efforts. Le soutien public à l’adhésion à l’UE est très élevé en Albanie, avec 91 % de personnes favorables, ce qui montre un fort engagement local.

**Prochaine étape** – L’Albanie vise à ouvrir ses derniers chapitres de négociation avec l’UE cette année, se rapprochant ainsi de l’adhésion complète d’ici 2030. Le nouveau bureau aidera à coordonner ces efforts et à assister les parlements de la région pour travailler plus étroitement avec l’UE. Des réformes et une coopération continues sont attendues.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’ouverture du bureau du Parlement européen pour les Balkans occidentaux à Tirana marque une étape importante pour soutenir l’Albanie et ses voisins sur la voie de l’adhésion à l’UE et d’une coopération régionale renforcée.
articles.personality_title_es: El Parlamento Europeo abre nueva oficina en Tirana para impulsar la cooperación en los Balcanes Occidentales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los Balcanes Occidentales son un grupo de países en el sureste de Europa que trabajan para unirse a la Unión Europea (UE). Albania, uno de estos países, se está preparando activamente para ser miembro de la UE para 2030.

**Qué pasó** – Pronto se abrirá una nueva oficina del Parlamento Europeo (PE) para los Balcanes Occidentales en Tirana, la capital de Albania. La oficina fue recibida por Elisa Spiropali, presidenta de la Asamblea de Albania, el embajador de la UE Silvio Gonzato, y Tatiana Mrazikova, jefa de la nueva oficina. Esta oficina servirá como punto de conexión entre el Parlamento Europeo y los países de los Balcanes Occidentales.

**Impacto** – Esta oficina acelerará la cooperación y el apoyo entre los países de los Balcanes Occidentales y el Parlamento Europeo. Ayudará a Albania y sus vecinos a trabajar juntos en reformas importantes y proyectos políticos. La oficina fortalece el papel de Albania en liderar estos esfuerzos. El apoyo público a la membresía en la UE es muy alto en Albania, con un 91 % a favor, lo que muestra un fuerte compromiso local.

**Próximo paso** – Albania espera abrir sus últimos capítulos de negociación con la UE este año, acercándose a la membresía completa para 2030. La nueva oficina ayudará a coordinar estos esfuerzos y asistirá a los parlamentos de la región para trabajar más estrechamente con la UE. Se esperan reformas y cooperación continuas.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La apertura de la oficina del Parlamento Europeo para los Balcanes Occidentales en Tirana marca un paso importante para apoyar a Albania y sus vecinos en su camino hacia la membresía en la UE y una cooperación regional más fuerte.
